description: Assessment to support OTC rehydration and anti-motility advice for uncomplicated acute diarrhoea.
inclusion: Adults and young people aged 12 years and over with sudden onset loose stools.
Symptoms lasting less than 5 days without systemic red flags.
exclusion: Bloody stools or signs of severe dehydration.
Recent foreign travel with systemic symptoms.
safetyNetting: Seek urgent care if stool becomes bloody, severe abdominal pain develops, or confusion occurs.
Return if diarrhoea persists beyond 5 days or new fever appears.
Maintain hydration and seek medical advice if unable to keep fluids down.

pass.label: Age suitable for OTC diarrhoea support.

result.headline: Refer - age under 12
result.summary: Children under 12 require GP assessment for acute diarrhoea.
actions: Arrange GP review or NHS 111 assessment for paediatric management.

warnings: Recent foreign travel - monitor for traveller's diarrhoea complications.
actions: Advise stool sample and GP review if symptoms persist beyond 48 hours.

warnings: Recent antibiotics increase risk of C. diff - advise urgent review if abdominal pain worsens.
actions: Counsel on red flag symptoms of C. difficile infection and ensure rapid referral if noted.

warnings: Vomiting present - advise small frequent sips of clear fluids.
actions: Recommend oral rehydration solution in small volumes until vomiting subsides.
Advise avoiding dairy, caffeine, and alcohol during acute phase.

pass.label: Red flag diarrhoea presentation - urgent referral.

result.headline: Urgent referral - bloody stool or severe dehydration
result.summary: Immediate medical assessment required due to red flag findings.
actions: Arrange same-day urgent care review; advise nil by mouth until assessed.

result.headline: Refer - immunocompromised patient
result.summary: Seek GP assessment due to higher complication risk.
actions: Arrange GP appointment within 24 hours and reinforce hydration advice.

pass.label: Frailty with frequent stools - consider escalation.

result.headline: Refer - frailty with high stool frequency
result.summary: Frailty plus frequent stools risks dehydration; arrange GP review.
actions: Contact GP to arrange same-day telephone review.
Ensure carer monitors fluid intake and urine output.

result.headline: Refer - prolonged diarrhoea
result.summary: Persistent diarrhoea beyond 5 days - arrange GP review for stool testing.
actions: Provide ORS supply for interim support while awaiting GP review.

trace.label: Criteria met for OTC diarrhoea support.

result.headline: Supply oral rehydration salts ± loperamide
result.summary: Provide oral rehydration therapy and consider loperamide where suitable.
actions: Supply oral rehydration salts - dissolve one sachet in 200 ml water after each loose stool (max 5 sachets/day).
If no contraindications, supply loperamide 2 mg: take two capsules initially then one after each loose stool (max 6 per day).
Advise bland diet (BRAT) and avoid dairy, caffeine, and alcohol during acute phase.

supply.product: Oral rehydration salts and loperamide 2 mg capsules
supply.dosage: ORS after each stool; loperamide up to 6 capsules per day (age ≥12)
supply.notes: Check for contraindications (bloody stool, fever, under 12, pregnancy) before supplying loperamide.

safetyNet: Return if symptoms persist beyond 48 hours despite treatment.
Seek urgent care if unable to maintain hydration or if stool becomes bloody.
Arrange GP review if abdominal pain worsens or fever develops.
